titleStmt.title: Grammar of Tamil (koṭun tamiḻ), by Beschi

repository.orgName: Bibliothèque nationale de France. Département des Manuscrits

summary.p: This is the French translation of the grammar of common Tamil (koṭun tamiḻ) written in Latin in 1728 by the Italian Jesuit Costantino Giuseppe Beschi (1680-1747).
The manuscript belonged to the collection of Édouard-Simon Ariel (1818-1854).

The manuscript is divided into six chapters each one made of a different number of sections: the first and the sixth chapters include seven sections; the second and the fourth ones have six sections; while the third chapter and the fifth one have eleven and five sections respectively. measure.p: 2 bifolio front guard leaves + 263 pages + 1 blank page + 2 bifolio back guard leaves
There are also two bifolios as front and back guard leaves.
The title is found on the first page where the main texts begins. The size of this page differs from the others being 240 x 165.
Only the verso of the last page is not numbered.

supportDesc.foliation: Original pagination on top (right or left) of page in Arabic numbers.

collation.desc: the front cover. Shelfmark on recto.
4 folios = front guard leaves. No foliation. Elements of binding.
264 pages = Grammar of Tamil (koṭun tamiḻ). 263 pages + 1 blank page.

supportDesc.condition: Good state of preservation, few boreholes caused by insects.

layout.p: 300mm (left margin) x 250 mm (right margin); 400/450 mm (bottom margin) x 300/400 mm (upper margin). Margin are marked with a pencil on the first pages. No row on the page. There is a secondary left margin of 1 cm (see pp. 117-118) when there are verb paradigms or noun declensions which are organised into columns of 16 cm width and 25,70 cm height. The columns also appear in the final appendices.

The text is well packaged. The writing is straight, neat and clean. There are no cancellations. Transliterations of words and phrases in Tamil are underlined and thus differentiated from the main text. In addition to the subdivision into Chapters and Articles, there is a straight line that marks the end of each chapter or article.
Tables are used for illustrating the consonants value.

desc.p: The manuscript belonged to Ariel's collection but the handwriting does not resemble Ariel's one but rather is similar to Gaston Laurent Cœurdoux (1691-1779) (cf. fond Brotier 89, fol. 68-71).

The distinction between e/ē and o/ō only occurs in the table of letters (pp. 6-8). In the running text of the grammar, whenever Tamil examples contain long ē/ō, the transcription is not modern and the lenght of vowel is not differentiated. The puḷḷi is not regularly used but rather one finds a diacritic consisting on a horizontal stroke palced above the final consonant when it should be considered as C+V, i.e. பொல (which appears as polā).
The periya Ra is written with a double loop.
The number 6 is of a peculiar form.

There are three stamps on the first page:
a red oval containing DON. N° without number.
a blue circle containing Societé Asiatique. Don. Collection Ariel. a red circle containing an eagle and the inscription BIBLIOTHEQUE IMPERIALE MSS..
The latter stamp was in use from 1852 to 1870 (cf. n. 36 in Josserand and Bruno 1960). It is also found on the last page (p. [264]).
Ownership statment in the form of the signature EAriel in black ink on top right side of page 1 and on bottom right side of page 263.
Number 2644 written in grey pencil on the last page (p. [264]).

There are some glosses on the right margin of pages 255 and 256 consisting in the transcriptions of Tamil numbers from 1 to 11, 20 to 21, 30 to 100, 900 to 1000 (unnnnu, iranndu, munna, nālu, Angiu, aru, Yegiu, Yetu, Onpatu, Pattu, Padiññoññu; Irrupatu, Irruppattonnu, Muppadu, Muppaduttonnu, Narpadu, Ainpadu, Arupadu, Yegiupadu, Yennpadu, Toñnurru, Nurru; Tullajiram, Ajiram).

p.p: The cover boards at the front and back of the book appear to be attached to the quires by the cords which are secured by means of channeling.

The boards and spine are covered with damp leather which is folded over the edges of the boards forming a turn-ins and glued down. Pastedowns of an initial and a final bifolios onto the inside of the board conceal these mechanism of the binding and also the channeling. The guard leaves are not numbered.
The whole manuscript is composed by eleven quires of two different size.The odd quires are made of four bifolios, while the even ones are made of eight bifolios.

origin.origDate: No internal date a apart from the one found in the watermark: 1742. Vinson (1867: 66bis), Vinson (1867-1868: 46), Vinson and Feer (1866–: 46), and Cabaton (1912: 1750) date it 1750, on ustated grounds.

provenance.p: This manuscript was copied in India, in Pondicherry and it comes from the collection of Édouard-Simon Ariel (1818-1854), a disciple of the well-known orientalist Eugène Burnouf (1801-1852). Ariel was employed by the French administration and learnt Tamil when he was in Pondicherry. When he died, his library of manuscript and printed books passed to the Société Asiatique and was afterwards transferred to the Bibliothèque Nationale in 1866 (Colas and Colas-Chauhan 1991: 387).

acquisition.p: The Société Asiatique transferred Ariel's collection to the Bibliothèque National in 1866 (Colas and Colas-Chauhan 1991: 387).

encodingDesc.p: Transliteration conventions ― puḷḷi, ō, and ē are used only if they are found in the manuscript. ― Abbreviations ― C = consonant, cf. = compare, f. = folio, ff. = folios, p. = page, pp. = pages, r = recto, U/u = unit (codicological and/or textual), V = vowel, v = verso.
